a.description: Our complete guide to links, buttons, and button-like inputs in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

a.title: Link Targets and 3.2.5
a.description: TL;DR: Regardless of what accessibility conformance level you target, do not arbitrarily open links in a new window or tab. If you are required to do so anyway, inform users in text. Overview Throughout this post I am going to use the terms browser window and tab interchangeably. While they…

a.title: Block Links, Cards, Clickable Regions, Etc.
a.description: Whether you call them cards, block links, or some other thing, the construct of making an area of content clickable (tappable, Enter-key-able, voice-activatable, etc.) is not new. While hit area size is mostly a usability issue, marketers often want a larger click area around their calls to action (…

a.title: <a>: The Anchor element
a.description: The HTML a element (or anchor element), with its href attribute, creates a hyperlink to web pages, files, email addresses, locations in the same page, or anything else a URL can address.

aria-details.title: Getting the details on aria-details | scottohara.me
aria-details.description: Introduced in ARIA 1.1, aria-details is meant to help convey that there is additional information available for a particular element a user is interacting with.

aria-label.title: Short note on aria-label, aria-labelledby, and aria-describedby
aria-label.description: Be careful when you use the aria-label, aria-labelledby, and aria-describedby attributes, because they do not work consistently with all HTML elements. This is a short note on when (and when not) to u

aria-labelledby.title: Short note on aria-label, aria-labelledby, and aria-describedby
aria-labelledby.description: Be careful when you use the aria-label, aria-labelledby, and aria-describedby attributes, because they do not work consistently with all HTML elements. This is a short note on when (and when not) to u

aria-describedby.title: Short note on aria-label, aria-labelledby, and aria-describedby
aria-describedby.description: Be careful when you use the aria-label, aria-labelledby, and aria-describedby attributes, because they do not work consistently with all HTML elements. This is a short note on when (and when not) to u

aria-describedby.title: Describing aria-describedby
aria-describedby.description: A well-designed user interface (UI) should clearly identify important content and controls. Often people correlate this to using prominent visual cues to help guide individuals through a task or point

article.title: Why You Should Choose HTML5 <article> Over <section> — Smashing Magazine
article.description: In this article, Bruce Lawson explains what use we have of `` and how authors should mark up headings that are hugely important to AT users.

article.title: <section>: The Generic Section element
article.description: The HTML section element represents a standalone section — which doesn’t have a more specific semantic element to represent it — contained within an HTML document.

button.title: A Complete Guide to Links and Buttons | CSS-Tricks
button.description: Our complete guide to links, buttons, and button-like inputs in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
button.author: Chris Coyier

button.title: Just use button -- A11ycasts #05
button.description: Talking about tabindex and custom controls is super fun, and we’ll definitely be doing more of it in the future. But I wanted to pause for a moment and shine...

button.title: Unbuttoning Buttons | scottohara.me
button.description: Regardless of how one might feel about using CSS to disguise an HTML element as another, it can’t be denied that it’s a common, and sometimes necessary, prac...

button.title: <button>: The Button element
button.description: The HTML button element represents a clickable button, used to submit forms or anywhere in a document for accessible, standard button functionality.

data.title: A Complete Guide to Data Attributes | CSS-Tricks
data.description: Everything you ever wanted to know about data attributes in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
data.author: Chris Coyier

details.title: Why <details> is Not an Accordion
details.description: tl;dr - <code><summary></code> is a button and buttons eat semantics

details.title: Details / Summary Are Not [insert control here]
details.description: Once major browsers started supporting <details> & <summary> developers immediately started to play with them to see what sorts of patterns they could enhance or replace. This is a good thing. Experimentation pushes boundaries, improves understanding. However, we need to be careful of christening th…

details.title: The details and summary elements | scottohara.me
details.description: The details and summary elements are two of HTML’s interactive elements and together are the elements that create a native disclosure widget.

dialog.title: Having an open dialog | scottohara.me
dialog.description: I’ve written about building accessible modal dialogs a few times over the past five-ish years. Most recently I dissected the current state of modal dialog ac...

dialog.title: <dialog>: The Dialog element
dialog.description: The HTML dialog element represents a dialog box or other interactive component, such as a dismissable alert, inspector, or subwindow.

figure.title: How do you figure? | scottohara.me
figure.description: Introduced as part of HTML5, the figure and figcaption elements are meant to create a meaningful markup structure that: provides a descriptive label to a pi...

figure.title: <figure>: The Figure with Optional Caption element
figure.description: The HTML figure (Figure With Optional Caption) element represents self-contained content, potentially with an optional caption, which is specified using the (figcaption) element.

lang.title: On Use of the Lang Attribute
lang.description: Way back in October I noticed this WHATWG HTML bug (26942) where someone asked why do these examples of <html> lack the lang attribute? I thought the answer from Hixie was a bit dismissive and not based on any data or real-world benefits of use, particularly in the context of…

meter.title: <meter>: The HTML Meter element
meter.description: The HTML meter element represents either a scalar value within a known range or a fractional value.

multiple.title: HTML attribute: multiple
multiple.description: The Boolean multiple attribute, if set, means the form control accepts one or more values. Valid for the email and file input types and the select, the manner by which the user opts for multiple values depends on the form control.

progress.title: <progress>: The Progress Indicator element
progress.description: The HTML progress element displays an indicator showing the completion progress of a task, typically displayed as a progress bar.

section.title: Why You Should Choose HTML5 <article> Over <section> — Smashing Magazine
section.description: In this article, Bruce Lawson explains what use we have of `` and how authors should mark up headings that are hugely important to AT users.

section.title: <section>: The Generic Section element
section.description: The HTML section element represents a standalone section — which doesn’t have a more specific semantic element to represent it — contained within an HTML document.

select.title: <select> your poison - 24 Accessibility
select.description: If the web accessibility community were to somehow collectively agree on a single rallying cry, it could easily be “use native, semantic HTML elements.” This, like most things in accessibility, is an oversimplification, but it is a helpful one. As 2019 draws to a close, many of the popular component…

select.title: <select> your poison part 2: test all the things - 24 Accessibility
select.description: TL:DR; Jump straight to the recommendations In part 1 of this deep dive, we took a broad look at both how the native <select> element works across browsers and platforms, and the current state of accessible custom select component implementations. It’s necessary to look at how fragmented current sel…

select.title: <select>
select.description: The HTML select element represents a control that provides a menu of options

svg.title: Accessible SVGs | CSS-Tricks
svg.description: Scalable Vector Graphic (SVG) is emerging as the preferred graphic format to use on the web today. Are you abandoning the icon font or replacing old pg,

title.title: The Trials and Tribulations of the Title Attribute - 24 Accessibility
title.description: Scott O’Hara returns, not with prose, but with a little history on the title attribute, it’s unintended misuse by developers, and where it can and should be used to improve the accessibility on your website.

title.title: Using the HTML title attribute – Updated March 2020
title.description: Note: This post has the same content as our 2013 post. They each originally addressed different aspects of the title attribute, but now they match. We are keeping both of them to account for inb

typedate.title: Is input type=“date” ready for use in accessible websites? - Hassell Inclusion
typedate.description: One of the ‘new’ HTML5 elements - input type=“date” - was intended to simplify the collection of dates on websites, and to reduce user errors whilst doing so. So is it well supported? And does using it help make forms more accessible? We took date inputs for a test drive with different browsers and …

typedate.title: <input type=“date”>
typedate.description: input elements of type=“date” create input fields that let the user enter a date, either with a textbox that validates the input or a special date picker interface.

typesearch.title: Maybe Ignore type=search
typesearch.description: Another case of the headline saying it all. If you have a valid, accessible search field (with a useful, sensible label) then you can probably ignore type=”search” and use type=”text” instead. I made a code sample you can use for testing in your preferred set-up; it is what I used…

typesearch.title: <input type=“search”>
typesearch.description: input elements of type search are text fields designed for the user to enter search queries into. These are functionally identical to text inputs, but may be styled differently by the user agent.

typenumber.title: Why the GOV.UK Design System team changed the input type for numbers
typenumber.description: We take a look at why the GOV.UK Design System changed the element it uses for inputting numbers, making it more accessible and easier to use
typenumber.author: Hanna Laakso, GDS, Frontend Developer

typenumber.title: You probably don’t need input type=“number”
typenumber.description: Last week I got a call from my bank regarding a wire transfer I had just scheduled. The customer support guy had me repeat everything back to him because there seemed to be a problem with the information. “Hmmmm, everything you said is right right except the last 3 digits of the account number.”
typenumber.author: Brad Frost

typenumber.title: <input type=“number”>
typenumber.description: input elements of type number are used to let the user enter a number. They include built-in validation to reject non-numerical entries.

video.title: How accessible is the HTML video player?
video.description: Comparing keyboard and screen reader accessibility of native video players.
video.author: Scott Vinkle

video.title: <video>: The Video Embed element
video.description: The HTML Video element (video) embeds a media player which supports video playback into the document. You can use video for audio content as well, but the audio element may provide a more appropriate user experience.
